page.title: 01Arthog and Hills to SE
page.content: The cottages in Arthog village on the south side of the A493, their gardens on the north side, are now mainly used as holiday homes. The vicarage serves the Church of Wales in Arthog as well as Fairbourne 3 miles SW. Deciduous woodlands rise steeply above the village to open hill farm country and the southern end of the Cader Idris range at Tyrau Mawr, the whole area forming part of Snowdonia National Park. The region is of interest to geologists and popular with walkers and tourists, especially Crogenan Lakes and the waterfalls of Afon Arthog. Six hill farms cover and extend beyond the area, rearing Welsh Black cattle and agile little mountain sheep with long tails. Welsh is the first language of the farming families.
